title: Visa Types
content: D-2 (Degree Program Visa): For undergraduate and postgraduate degrees. Requires IELTS proficiency. D-4 (Language Training Visa): For Korean language programs; usually no IELTS required but must pass TOPIK Level 2.

title: Things to Do and Avoid
content: Do: Submit complete documents (passport, transcripts, financial proof, SOP, etc.), Maintain a sufficient bank balance (usually ~₩20M or USD 15,400). Don't: Skip language proficiency preparation (IELTS/TOPIK), Delay application; observe intake timelines carefully.

title: Summary
content: This chunk of knowledge provides a structured overview addressing academic eligibility, intake periods, costs, visa categories, and student FAQs. Ideal for consultancies to embed in a chatbot, enhancing both authority and usability.

title: Intakes and Application Periods
content: Spring Intake: Classes begin in April; application window is October–December (previous year). Fall Intake: Classes begin in September; apply between April–July.

title: Estimated Costs Annually
content: Tuition Fees: UG: ₩3.7M–₩8.6M (~$3,000–$6,000 per year). Additional Costs: Visa & application: $70–$80 (approx), Living expenses: ₩900,000/month (~$700); dorms or off-campus vary, Health insurance: ₩60,000–₩100,000/month.

title: Overview - Nepali Students in South Korea
content: Ideal for use within a retrieval-based chatbot, it covers essentials like eligibility, timelines, costs, visa types, FAQs, and key dos and don'ts.

title: Minimum Requirements
content: GPA: Undergraduate: Minimum 2.8 in 10+2, Postgraduate: Minimum GPA 2.4 in Bachelor's degree. Language Proficiency: IELTS: Overall 5.5 (no band less than 5.0) across UG/PG programs, Graduate (PhD): IELTS 6.0 preferred. Gap Years Accepted: Up to 3 years for UG, up to 5 years for PG.

- Immigration permission required.
